s.text: Stools were positive for leukocytes and trace reducing substances.

Although generally thought to have a later presentation [ 1 ] than other primary intestinal malabsorption syndromes, recent reports of infants with SI deficiency indicate the existence of an early onset form (presentation of diarrhea at 2-16 weeks) that is complicated by severe malnutrition [ 2 ] . Starnes and Walsh [ 3 ] observed renal calculi in two adults with sucrase deficiency, but neither patient had evidence of hypercalcemia.
Physical examination showed an alert, nondysmorphic infant with severe reduction in muscle mass and subcutaneous fat.

Infants with hypercalcemia may have no obvious symptoms, but constitutional symptoms such as poor appetite, irritability, vomiting, FTT, or occasionally seizures may occur [ 7 ] . Classically, hypercalcemia leads to increased urine output and diminished stool frequency.

Classically, hypercalcemia leads to increased urine output and diminished stool frequency.
She had been growing well and thriving until weaned from breast milk to formula at age 4 months when she began to have frequent stools and poor weight gain.

Occasional patients may come to attention in late childhood or adulthood but careful history often indicates that symptoms have appeared earlier [ 18 19 ] . The mainstay of treatment is dietary restriction of sucrose-containing foods.

Sucrase deficiency may be especially common in indigenous Greenlanders (estimated 5%) and is accompanied most often by lactase deficiency [ 24 25 ] . Initial studies demonstrated that most SI mutations result in lack of enzyme protein (i.e.

In contrast, hypercalcemia frequently complicates congenital lactase deficiency [ 4 ] . The present case illustrates the occurrence of hypercalcemia and nephrocalcinosis as a clinically significant complication of SI deficiency in an infant and suggests that common mechanisms may lead to hypercalcemia in both SI and congenital lactase deficiency.

neutral-phosphate therapy) is of equal benefit and does not perturb calcium/phosphorus metabolism in children with phosphate-wasting rickets [ 6 ] . Infants with hypercalcemia may have no obvious symptoms, but constitutional symptoms such as poor appetite, irritability, vomiting, FTT, or occasionally seizures may occur [ 7 ] . Classically, hypercalcemia leads to increased urine output and diminished stool frequency.
We conclude that SI deficiency should be added to the list of disorders that can cause infantile hypercalcemia and particularly may be considered when accompanied by FTT and watery diarrhea.
Sucrase-isomaltase deficiency is a rare autosomal recessive disorder in which there is complete absence of sucrase and most of the maltase digestive activity.
